Intopia accessibility review

Accessibilty review of Status page

By Intopia for Atlassian
Created on 29/05/20

Introduction

Atlassian engaged Intopia to conduct an independent accessibility review of select features on the update product name. Accessibility is the extent to which a site or app is accessible to as many people as possible. Expert accessibility testers reviewed select pages and features of Status page against the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines from -

How you went

Status page tested very well for accessibility and is a credit to client's time and effort towards making the site accessible. Most of the issues identified were low priority issues, with only a few medium and high priority issues identified.

What youâ€™re doing well

  • The interface is keyboard friendly. Users that rely on the keyboard alone will be able to navigate and operate the interface easily. The focus outline which enables sighted keyboard users to see which component has keyboard focus is clear and applied consistently across the pages tested.
  • The sequence and structure of content is generally good. Screen reader users navigate content on a page linearly, making the order of content important. The order of content is consistent and makes it easy for content to be understood. Structural and navigational elements such as headings, lists and links are used well.

Your most critical issues

  • Search and Browse form fields are not associated with the correct error messages. This will cause screen reader users to hear the incorrect error message for these fields.
  • Focus is lost after certain interactions. When information changes dynamically, focus must be set via scripting otherwise focus can be lost and is often placed at a random position on the page. This impacts screen reader users and keyboard only users, who will navigate through content from this random location and be particularly confusing for screen reader users.

Issues

Page <title> is missing

  • Type: WCAG 2
  • Principle: Operable
  • Guideline: 2.4 Navigable
  • Success Criteria: 2.4.2 Page Titled (A)
  • Level: A
  • Platform: All
  • Technology:All
  • Severity: Medium
  • Element: Title
  • Component: Head
  • Page: About us
  • URL: /about-us
  • Ref: PC-8

What's the issue?

The About us page is missing a title.

Why it matters

Every page must have a page title. The page title is the first thing heard by screen reader users on page load, as well as when switching between browser tabs, so it is essential to wayfinding.

Our recommendation

Give the page a title by adding a <title> to the <head>. It is best practice to put the most unique (i.e. page specific) title information first, most generic (i.e. site name) last.

Code example

<title>Page title - Site title</title>


Related items should be marked up in a list

  • Type: WCAG 2
  • Principle: Perceivable
  • Guideline: 1.3 Adaptable
  • Success Criteria: 1.3.1 Info and Relationships (A)
  • Level: A
  • Platform: All
  • Technology:Screen reader
  • Severity: Medium
  • Element: Links
  • Component: Main navigation bar
  • Page: All pages
  • URL: https://test-site.com
  • Ref: PC-7

What's the issue?

The links in the navigation are related items and have not been marked up in a list.

Why it matters

Assistive technology relies on semantically meaningful HTML to provide the appropriate support to users. Without list mark-up in the HTML, assistive technologies cannot provide shortcuts which allow users to navigate the lists quickly. Screen readers will not be able to announce the number of lists in the item or other supporting information.

Our recommendation

A list of items should be marked up as an ordered (numbered) list, unordered (bullet) list or a definition list. Mark up the links in the navigation in an unordered list.

Code example

<ul>

<li>Test 1</li>

<li>Test 2</li>

</ul>
